awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multiscale Thermomechanical Analysis of Nanomaterials and Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
0955096
Li


This CAREER project seeks to develop a theory and methodology for analysis of multiscale thermomechanical nanomaterials and structures.  The operation of many ultrasmall devices involves strong thermomechanical interactions. However, a gap exists between the existing continuum and atomistic models. Accurate and efficient computational tools are not available for systematic analysis of such systems. This research aims to fill this gap by introducing novel thermomechanical models to bridge the continuum and atomistic theories. Computational tools will be developed for analysis and optimization of nano -thermomechanical systems.

Intellectual Merit: A mathematical model describing the thermomechanical interactions on the atomistic level and a quasi-continuum theory with a higher level of abstraction will be established. A multiscale computational approach, combining the thermomechanical models will be developed. Computational analysis of nanoscale resonators, atomic force microscope heaters and composite materials will be conducted to address a set of technologically important issues such as thermal dissipation, thermal management and surface effects in these devices and materials. In addition, a concept of mechanical design of thermal transport in materials is to be explored.

Broader Impacts: The proposed research will provide theoretical and computational models that bridge the gap between pure atomistic and continuum models. Research results will address the fundamental issues of nanoscale thermomechanical interactions. Project outcomes will be disseminated through technical publications. Software tools developed in conjunction with this project will be made available to the thermal transport and mechanics communities. In addition, the PI will establish a web portal and engage in outreach with K-12, undergraduate and graduate students through simulation-based learning and discovery.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This CAREER project develops a theory and a computational model for multiscale thermomechanical analysis of nanomaterials and nanostructures. There are three major research components in the proposed project. The first component contains a theory of nanoscale thermomechanics describing the thermomechanical interactions on the atomistic level and a quasicontinuum thermomechanics theory with a higher level of abstraction. The second component proposes a multiscale computational approach combining the nano and quasicontinuum thermomechanical theories with the continuum thermomechanical theory for efficient and accurate analysis of nanomaterials and nanostructures. Molecular dynamics and experimental data have been used to validate the mathematical models and the computational implementation. The third component consists of computational analysis of nano-resonators, nanocomposite materials and nanocomposite thermal actuators to address several technologically important issues such as thermal dissipation, thermal management and surface effects in these nano devices and materials. In addition, a concept of mechanical design of thermal transport in nanomaterials has also been explored.

The intellectual merit of this research includes the proposition of the atomistic and quasicontinuum thermomechanical models, the development of a multiscale approach combining the atomistic, quasicontinuum and continuum thermomechanical theories for efficient and accurate analysis of nanomaterials and nanostructures, and the exploration of the concept of mechanical design of phonon thermal transport. 

The research has provided theoretical and computational models that bridge the gap between the pure atomistic and the macroscopic continuum models. Our research results have addressed several fundamental issues of thermal dissipation, thermal management and surface effects in nanoscale devices and materials, and expanded the design and control space of thermal transport in nanomaterials and nanostructures. Research results have been published in peer reviewed journals and conferences. Software tools developed in this research project have been made available to researchers and students. Graduate and undergraduate students have participated in this project. Due to the multidisciplinary nature of this research, students engaged in this research have gained exposure to a variety of areas such as thermal transport, nanomechanics, solid state physics, and numerical analysis. A graduate level course on nanomechanics has been developed and taught at Clemson University. The PI has established a ``CTEMS'' web portal and is extending the research impacts to K-12, undergraduate and graduate students as well as the professionals through simulation-based learning and discovery.


Last Modified: 06/29/2016
Modified by: Gang Li
